perturbation.original_text: 12.1 The Company and Consultant each acknowledge and agree that the only relationship of the Consultant to the Company created by this Agreement shall for all purposes be that of a contractor, and all persons employed or engaged by the Consultant, including David Wolfin in connection herewith shall for all purposes be considered to be employed or engaged, as applicable, by the Consultant and not by the Company. The Company shall have no obligation whatsoever to pay or compensate the Consultant and/or any representative of the Consultant including David Wolfin, for taxes of any kind whatsoever that arise out of or with respect to any Consulting Fee, or any other fee, remuneration or compensation provided to the Consultant under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.1 The Company and Consultant each acknowledge and agree that the only relationship of the Consultant to the Company created by this Agreement shall for all purposes be that of an employee, and all persons employed or engaged by the Consultant, including David Wolfin in connection herewith shall for all purposes be considered to be employed or engaged, as applicable, by the Company and not by the Consultant. The Company shall have no obligation whatsoever to pay or compensate the Consultant and/or any representative of the Consultant including David Wolfin, for taxes of any kind whatsoever that arise out of or with respect to any Consulting Fee, or any other fee, remuneration or compensation provided to the Consultant under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'contractor' to 'employee' directly contradicts the stated intent to establish a contractor relationship. This misclassification creates confusion regarding employment rights, tax obligations, and liability for both parties. It creates risk for the company as misclassifying someone as a contractor when they are an employee is a tax and legal violation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Employment Standards Act, Income Tax Act (Canada), common law principles regarding contractor vs. employee relationships.

perturbation.original_text: 3.1 The Company will pay the Consultant basic remuneration for its services in the sum of $10,000 per month (the "Consulting Fee") commencing on the 1st day of February, 2020, and payable on the last day of each month thereafter up to and including the 31st day of January, 2025, together with any such increments thereto as the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors of the Company may from time to time determine. In addition, the Company will pay to the Consultant all reasonable expenses of the Consultant as agreed to from time to time which are incurred by the Consultant in delivery of the Services, based on monthly invoices submitted to the Company, including copies of all paid receipts; plus harmonized sales taxes or goods and services taxes, as the case may be, in addition to the Consulting Fees, which taxes will be remitted by the Consultant to the Canada Revenue Agency.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.1 The Company will pay the Consultant basic remuneration for its services in the sum of $10,000 per month (the "Consulting Fee") commencing on the 1st day of February, 2020, and payable on the last day of each month thereafter up to and including the 31st day of January, 2025, together with any such increments thereto as the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors of the Company may from time to time determine. In addition, the Company may pay expenses of the Consultant at the company's discretion. plus harmonized sales taxes or goods and services taxes, as the case may be, in addition to the Consulting Fees, which taxes will be remitted by the Company to the Canada Revenue Agency.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'will pay' to 'may pay' is creating a misaligned terminology because it makes reimbursements discretionary. As well as changing 'remitted by the Consultant' to 'remitted by the company'.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Tax laws pertaining to contractor expenses and revenue recognition. These expenses are legally bound to who is supposed to remit them.

perturbation.original_text: 8.1 The Consultant agrees that all discoveries, maps, technical studies, plans, spreadsheets, documents, inventions, copyright, software, improvements, know-how or other intellectual property, whether or not patentable or copyrightable, created by the Consultant during the Term of this Agreement pertaining to any service, matter, thing, process or method related to this Agreement (the "Works") will be the sole and absolute property of the Company. The Consultant will keep and maintain adequate and current written records of all Works made, which records will be available at all times to the Company and will remain the sole property of the Company.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.1 The Consultant agrees that all discoveries, maps, technical studies, plans, spreadsheets, documents, inventions, copyright, software, improvements, know-how or other intellectual property, whether or not patentable or copyrightable, created by the Consultant during the Term of this Agreement pertaining to any service, matter, thing, process or method related to this Agreement (the "Works") will be jointly owned by the Consultant and the Company. The Consultant will keep and maintain adequate and current written records of all Works made, which records will be available at all times to both parties and will be jointly owned by the Company and Consultant.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'sole and absolute property of the Company' to 'jointly owned by the Consultant and the Company' directly contradicts the initial assignment of intellectual property rights. Intellectual property laws are specific about ownership, and a joint ownership provision could be difficult to enforce and manage, especially if the agreement does not specify how joint rights are managed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Copyright Act (Canada), Patent Act (Canada), Trade-marks Act (Canada), and associated common law principles regarding intellectual property ownership.
